algorithms.sectionHeader: NOTES ON THE INCUBATION AND REARING OF THE PIPING PLOVER
algorithms.table: (\0x25A0Charadrius melodus ) By John R. Quinn (Staff Artist) and Ryan B. Walden (Supervisor, Live Animal Programme) (Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, Penna, U.S.A.)
algorithms.bodyText: The wide, bare sand beaches of eastern North America, from southern Saskatchewan to North Carolina and inland to northwestern Indiana are the summer homes and breeding grounds of the Piping Plover (<Charadrius melodus). The ventriloquial " peep-lo " call helps little in locating this pale, little bird as it runs along the shore or leaps lightly into the air to skim the crest of a breaker. Once nearly exterminated, it is now returning as a breeding species along the New Jersey coast. The busy resorts with their hordes of bathers and feral cats and dogs comprise its major enemies today. The very survival of the Piping Plover depends on the effectiveness of its protective colouration and the locating of its nest. The nest is usually a shallow hole, several of which are made by the male and one is selected by the female. The site is usually on the bare beach, among sparse beach grass, or at the base of a low sand dune. It was only with a great deal of difficulty that John Quinn secured the eggs of this species. The first nest was rather unusual in that it was located on the seaward side of a dune, concealed in dune grass. The second nest was in a more conventional location on the open beach. In both cases the adults stole away from the nests as they were approached and came back to one side to distract the intruder. The locations of the nests were learned by retiring and watching the parents with a spotting scope until they returned to their nests. Each nest contained four, buffy, speckled eggs which were almost invisible against the bits of shell and pebbles that lined the edges of the cavity. The birds can be found on the beaches from late March to late October, but the majority of the breeders come here in April and May and have departed by the middle of August. The nests from which the eggs were obtained were located on 18th June and appeared to be quite fresh. Two eggs were taken from each nest and placed in a still-air incubator. The temperature was 99-4* F.; and because

146 J. R. QUINN AND R. B. WALDEN-THE PIPING PLOVER of previous problems of the membrane drying out, the decision was made to keep the humidity at 78 per cent. The eggs were turned twice a day, and in seventeen days the first egg began to pip. All four of the eggs hatched within 10 hours of the first one. Three of the young birds appeared to be in very fine health, but the fourth was rather weak and, much to our regret, died 3 days later. The four chicks were put in a small brooder which was approximately 93 0 F. for the first week ; the temperature was then reduced to between 85* and 89* F. The development of the chicks seemed to indicate that only enough heat was needed to avoid chilling them, as they spent most of their time at the edges of the brooder where the temperature was as low as 8o* F. After twenty-four hours a mixture of Purina F and M, chopped egg yolk and the smallest mealworms available was fed. They picked at the moving worms very readily and were soon eating the entire mixture. Because of the variety of insects, crustaceans, molluscs, and other small, marine animals and their eggs which serve as natural food for the Piping Plover in the wild, a wide choice of food was also offered the captive chicks. Large mealworms were eaten when the birds were 3 days old, and other insect life such as aquatic tubifex worms and roaches were fed with success. This species of plover is an extremely active bird in captivity ; how- ever, it should do very well if provided with abundant room and a variety of food. The problem of toe picking was experienced at about one week, but was alleviated at once with the increase of live food. The birds developed quite rapidly, but all three of them were slow to fly which could likely be accounted for by the lack of flight room. Very little has been published on the breeding of shore birds in captivity, and we would be very interested in corresponding with anyone who has had experience with the propagating of any of the species. We feel that as civilization advances all over the world, shore birds will suffer particularly ; and so the propagation of this family in captivity may mean the difference of life and death for many species. PS.--The Plovers are now adult, or nearly so, and will be given to the Philadelphia Zoo (Mr. John Griswold).

(.Aegithalos caudatus) By W. Painter (Farnham, Surrey, England) During the last winter I received a pair of Long-tailed Tits, Aegithalos caudatus , from the collection of a recently deceased aviculturist. During the cold weather I housed them in an 8 feet by 6 feet bird room. This faced south and was heated by a paraffin stove to a temperature of about 45 degrees Fahrenheit. In spring they were transferred to an outdoor aviary at the end of the garden. This was an all-wire structure, 9 feet by 16 feet, built against and partly under a stand of silver birch trees, with a small stream just beyond it. The aviary itself was very heavily planted with shrubs and creepers. The Long-tailed Tits shared the aviary with a hen Lesser White- throat, a cock Black Redstart, and a pair of Yellow Wagtails which nested and reared five young during the breeding season. Relations between these birds seemed quite amicable. The birds were fed on " Avi-vite " soft-food, blowfly maggots, and occasional grated cheese. In addition the vegetation in and around the aviary provided a number of live insects. The tits kept together and the cock was heard at times to utter a quiet warbling song and seen performing a display, puffing out his feathers and hopping sideways along a perch above that on which the hen was sitting. They were visited almost daily by a wild cock that would come and perch on the aviary, and this seemed to stimulate the breeding behaviour of the aviary pair. In the hope that they would try to breed, the birds were supplied with nest-material consisting of kapok, moss, white cat's fur, lichen, and spider's web. They chose a nest-site in a berberis shrub with many slender thorny stems, about three feet from the ground ; the site being apparently selected by the male, performing his fluffed display as he did so. Nest-building began in early May but the rate of progress appeared to be governed by the amount of spiders' webs available for binding it. Considerable difficulty was experienced in providing sufficient of this and as a result the nest was not complete until late May. Fresh spiders' webs, which were mostly found low in hedgerows, were collected on a piece of wire bent into a loop at the end, and these were placed on the end of a perch, where the birds collected them into small balls and added them to the structure. Cobwebs were collected from the corners of sheds and also offered, but the birds preferred the fresh ones when available. Lichen was offered on pieces of bark and the birds tore off flakes and attempted to stick them to the outside of the nest, the scarcity of spiders' webs making this a little difficult. At first the birds appeared

to use the nest merely for roosting and it was not until early June that it became apparent that one of the birds was on the nest for most of the time, presumably incubating. I was reluctant to examine the nest and upset the pair and possibly damage the structure, and so little precise data is available. About mid-June fragments of egg-shell were found in the aviary, indicating that hatching had occurred. For about five days after this one bird was usually on the nest while the other continually searched the vegetation for insects. After about five days both adults shared the task of food collecting. At this period Wood Ant pupae were added to their diet, and it was noted that they were taking any insects that could be found, especially aphis. In early July a single young one was at last seen out of the nest, accompanying its parents. An examination of the now empty nest revealed no evidence of the existence of either other eggs or young. As described, W. Painter has bred the Long-tailed Tit Aegithalos caudatus. It is believed that this may be a first success. Any member or reader knowing of a previous breeding of this species in Great Britain or Northern Ireland is requested to communi- cate at once with the Hon. Secretary.
algorithms.figure: (Coryphospingus cristatus) By Jeffrey Trollope (Hounslow, Middlesex, England) Introduction
algorithms.bodyText: C. cristatus has a wide range in South America, G. Carmichael Low (1929) gives its distribution as Guiana, Brazil, Bolivia, Paraguay, Argentine. This species was bred in France by Monsieur A. Decoux during 1926. Its congeneric the Pileated Finch (C. pileatus) has been bred on several occasions, the earliest record was I believe by Mrs. H. Williams in 1905.

Breast and most of underparts vinous, wings, back and tail dark brown. Rump vinous, crest carmine edged with black, beak, upper mandible dark grey, lower light grey. There is a very small pale " whitish " patch on the chin. The eyes are circled by a narrow skin margin varying from pale yellowish to almost white, the iris is brown. Legs are usually light grey. Hen General colour light brown, vinous on breast, rump and vent. Legs, beak, eye margin and iris the same as cock. The hen has a small crest which is the same light brown colour as most of the plumage. Details of Individuals and Nesting The pair of birds concerned (pair 44 A ") was purchased on 12th May, 1964. After a brief period of acclimatization they were released into an outside flight. During June the hen went into moult and 1964 passed without interest. In April, 1965, they were released into a planted aviary 12 feet by 8 feet by 10 feet, the cock displayed to the hen and often vigorously chased her. On 3rd June a very neatly woven nest of grasses, lined with fine roots, was found in a canary nest-cup, which had been nailed to a support beam. No eggs were laid and a cock St. Helena Waxbill (Estrilda astrild ) filled it with green privet leaves. A second pair of Red-Crested Finches (pair 44 B ") was purchased on 14th June and housed in an adjoining aviary. The two pairs could see each other and the cocks spent a good deal of time in competitive display and song. Apart from hen-chasing by both cocks, there was no other 44 nesting " activity in 1965. Pair 44 A " was released into the 12 foot by 8 foot aviary on 14th May,

1966, which they shared with Talpacoti Doves (Columbigallina talpacoti), Harlequin Quail ( Coturnix delegorguei) , Quail Finches ( Ortygospiza articollis ), Pin-tailed Nonpareils ( Erthyura prasina ) and Pearl-headed Silverbills ( Odontospiza caniceps ), one pair of each species. " Pair B " were kept out of visual and vocal contact, as I feared the competitive display and song might distract them, so all further comment will refer to pair " A ". Among the various nesting receptacles in the aviary, was a roughly fashioned cup of J-inch wire mesh. This was fixed in a small tree about 4 feet above ground, some leafy twigs were stuck around the rim forming a screen, and a small amount of dried grass pushed into the " cup 55 . The hen flew to this site on 4th June with a grass stem, by the 6th a nest of grass neatly lined with upholsterer's fibre had been finished. An egg was laid on the 15th, a second on the 16th and the hen commenced incubation. The nest was examined on the 23rd and there were three eggs. During incubation the cock fed the hen, although she left the nest to chase other birds from the site and to feed. On the morning of the 27th there were three young birds in the nest, which were probably hatched the day before. They were dark grey in colour and showed traces of greyish white nestling down. The hen brooded them closely, the cock flying to the nest with earwigs, flies and gentles. Mealworms and " sluis " were placed in the feeding site the following day. The mealworms were given to the young immediately, and remained the preferred live food. From this time the hen brooded the young night and early morning. Both parents were busy and atten- tive " feeders ", the chicks showed a yellow edged pinkish red gape when " begging ". Nest sanitation was carried out by the hen, in most cases droppings carried from the nest were eaten. One youngster left the nest on the evening of 5th July. It was pouring with rain, the chick was well feathered and half flapped, half hopped, around the aviary. The hen was very bold, flying around my head. An attempt was made to replace the chick in the nest, (a forlorn hope), it scrambled out again immediately. To my surprise it was alive the next morning, looked dry and active and was preening in a very " adult " fashion. A second chick left the nest on the 7th, the hen was continually chasing away the Harlequin Quail and Quail Finches from her chicks on the ground. She also tried, usually without success, to coax them to perch above ground by holding a mealworm in her beak, flying to the chick and as soon as it " begged " she hopped above ground by clinging to the aviary netting or a twig. If the chick followed she would go a little higher, often the chick would follow until 4 or 5 feet above the ground then flap down ; the hen would then repeat this coaxing with great persistence. The second youngster died on the 8th, the third left the nest on the 9th and died the same day. Both parents continued to guard

and feed the survivor, who seemed to be very backward in perching and flying. The same nest was relined with upholsterer's fibre on the 19th and an egg was laid on the 21st, incubation commenced at once and a second egg was laid on the 23rd. During incubation the cock fed the youngster of the first clutch and the hen. He began to feed the chick on seed on the 25th and the youngster was feeding itself on the 27th. It was now like the hen except for lack of vinous colouration on rump etc. One chick of the second clutch hatched on 1st August. The remaining egg was " clear ". I had to go away for two weeks on the 3rd, and the chick of the first clutch was dead that morning. It was 36 days old and independent of its parents, but its movements had been unco-ordinated since it was about 14 days old. The solitary chick of the second clutch showed the same gape colour, nestling down etc. as the first brood. All appeared well so I left the birds in charge of a friend, hoping for better luck with the second " round ". Unfortunately I found the body of this chick when I returned home, and estimated its age to be about 14 days. The five eggs laid were unmarked white ovals rather attenuated towards the small end. Only one egg was measured, the " clear " in the second clutch which was 20-2 by 14'imm. Incubation period for both clutches was approxi- mately 11 days. Food Mixed millets, small canary, " wild " seed, maw, millet sprays and soaked seed are always available, plus seeding grasses, powdered cuttlefish, oystershell etc. Maggots, whiteworm and any live food available are given ad-lib. Millet and small canary form the basic seed diet of the adults. Millet sprays, seeding grasses are taken with relish. Wild seed is picked over, maw is ignored, all live food is favoured except whiteworm. There is little doubt that failure to rear the young was due to dietary deficiency. When the chicks left the nest I dusted maggots and mealworms with P.Y.M. and gave Bemax mixed with water. Although the adults ate the Bemax, the young appeared to be given nothing but live food, the one exception was the first chick hatched which was fed seed by the cock when it was about 28 days old. Voice A loud " Thik-tic " is the most often heard note from both sexes. When the aviary is entered or they have young out of the nest, a " flatter " sounding " Thik-tac " is given. The cock has a harsh " Zurr-zurr ", and a series of quiet chirruping notes which are always given from cover. These notes remind me of a very subdued and

" musical "! version of a House Sparrow's chirruping notes. The song of the cock is loud and sustained. It is usually prefaced by a very loud, shrill " Wheeee-wheeee " sometimes followed by several shorter versions of this same sound, in quick succession. Variations on these three sounds seem to be the main components of the full song.

C. cristatus is an active bird with strong flight; both pairs have been wintered without heat in a dry draught-free shelter with artificial light provided till 9 p.m. Their behaviour is generally aggressive, even without being in " breeding condition " both sexes are inclined to keep smaller birds on the move. However, in my limited aviary space, this could be said of many birds, some of which are not " territorial ". Perhaps to get a true picture two pairs would have to be kept in a large " wilderness " aviary. A good deal of time is spent on, or near, the ground, locomotion on the ground is always by hopping. When a gentle or any live food is taken they fly to a low perch in cover to eat it. The tail is often cocked when alighting on a perch at a similar angle to that of the Blackbird, it is frequently cocked when hopping on the ground. The display of the male bird is vigorous, the " object " seems to be to " drive " the hen to the ground. On several occasions the cock has struck the hen during this " driving " or " chasing ", although in such a state of excitement this could well be accidental. When the hen reaches the ground she stands facing the cock as he alights. His crest is erected and fanned out, the body posture is erect with the neck stretched. Head and neck are swung from side to side with a rhythmic motion, he sings during this display period. The hen keeps facing the cock and breaks " contact " by flying away, sometimes the cock resumes the " chase ". This display pattern was the same for both pairs. Copulation has been witnessed twice only, in both cases the hen was perched. Once the hen was seen lying prone, with beak, head, body, and tail, flat on the ground and with wings half open. (This is difficult to describe, but perhaps the nearest one can get would be to say it resembled a " flat " sun bathing posture.) The cock flew down and alighted on the rump of the hen with wings beating, then flew away, the hen following. He was singing and the crest was erected and fanned as he touched the hen's rump. It would appear that the hen's posture was an unusual one for a passerine to adopt. When the hen left the nest during incubation the cock would fly to her and give an open beak upright posture, this occurred every time the hen was seen to leave the nest and was only given when the hen was perched.

As described, J. Trollope has bred the Red-crested Finch Coryphos- pingus cristatus. It is believed that this may be a first success. Any member or reader knowing of a previous breeding of this species in Great Britain or Northern Ireland is requested to communicate at once with the Hon. Secretary.
algorithms.table: * * * REFERENCE Decoux, A. (1927). Breeding the Red-Crested Finch in France. Avicultural Mag. Vol. V. * * * BREEDING THE WHEATEAR (Oenanthe 0. oenanthe (L.)) By Philip Wayre (Great Witchingham, Norfolk, England)
algorithms.bodyText: During the spring of 1965 a pair of Wheatears, originally obtained from Spain, bred in one of the small aviaries in the Norfolk Wildlife Park. The enclosure is constructed of half-inch mesh wire-netting on pressure creosoted timber, and measures 10 feet wide, 12 feet deep and 7 feet high. The inside has been landscaped, a small turf-covered bank running down one side and across the back, and furnished with pieces of rock, a tree stump and growing shrubs. An artificial rabbit-burrow was constructed, running back into the bank, to complete as nearly as possible a replica of typical Wheatear habitat. The burrow consists of a bottomless box, two feet long and six inches square, buried in the ground. One end is left open and a removable lid placed over the far end above the nest chamber. The burrow runs uphill to prevent flooding in wet weather. Food in the form of insectivorous mixture, live maggots and meal- worms is given in a shallow dish inside a small natural looking cave built of stone, thus remaining dry in all weathers. The adults were introduced to the aviary in April 1965, the hen being put out two weeks before the cock to give her time to settle and to prevent the cock becoming aggressive. The hen was first missed on 30th May and apparently began to incubate on that date. On 15th June the cover over the top of the nest chamber was removed when the female was out feeding in the evening. Hatching had started and the nest contained two chicks and three eggs. On 24th June one chick was found dead outside the nest-burrow with wounds on its back and head. It had apparently been pulled out and attacked by one or both parents. There was no sign of the other chick. Early in July the cock died, but the hen was already incubating her second clutch for they hatched on 15th July. A fortnight later two

chicks were coming to the entrance of the burrow to beg for food. The hen reared them without trouble until they were able to fend for themselves. Early this year (1966) the same adult hen was put in the aviary and two weeks later the young male bred last year joined her. Towards the end of May the female was observed on several occasions carrying dead grass and roots into the burrow and on 4th June she began to incubate a clutch of five eggs. They apparently hatched on 19th June and from then on both adult birds were seen to take food to the young, although the hen did the bulk of the feeding. For the first week in addition to their normal food, chopped mealworms were provided in a separate dish. On 6th July the nest was examined and found to contain two fully feathered chicks both of which showed signs of crippled feet, although they were able to run when placed on the ground. Young Wheatears in the wild run out of their nest-burrows from the age of ten days onwards to meet the adults returning with food. This behaviour had never been seen in the captive birds, possibly on account of members of the public so often looking at them, so it was decided to shut them out of their burrow for a few hours each day, increasing the period gradually. At the end of a week one chick was perching quite normally and showed no sign of any deformity. The other remained crippled in one foot and died some weeks later. The healthy chick turned out to be a female and was separated from its parents in late September. As described by Philip Wayre, the Wheatear Oenanthe oenanthe has been bred at the Norfolk Wildlife Park. It is believed that this may be a first success. Any member or reader knowing of a previous breeding of this species in Great Britain or Northern Ireland is requested to communicate at once with the Hon. Secretary.
algorithms.reference: W. H. BROWN-BREEDING MASSENA's LORIKEET
algorithms.bodyText: (Trichoglossus haematod mas send) By W. H. Brown (Tonbridge, Kent, England) On 17th September, 1965, I received from Dr. Ken Searle of Hong Kong, a beautiful pair of lorikeets. These were identified as Massena's Lorikeets which I will now describe. They are approximately 10 inches in length and I have been unable to find any difference between the sexes. The facial areas are blue, as are the crown and the forehead, followed by a dull purple band and a bright yellow-green nuchal collar. The throat is also a deep, dull purple and the breast is a brilliant red. Each of the breast feathers is scaled with a rich, dark blue giving a striped effect. The abdomen is green with yellow markings, and the thighs and legs are green and yellow striped. The bill of the adult is orange. Altogether a really lovely bird. On opening the box they had travelled in I found that the hen had laid two eggs which seemed a pretty good start, but these I disposed of at once. The birds were kept in a temperature-controlled room for a month with the temperature being brought down a little every day. I then put them into one of my outdoor flights, which measures 12 feet by 6 feet by 3 feet, with a house at the end, into which they were shut every evening during the following winter. This flight and all of my other outdoor flights are unheated. They went right through the winter without a spot of trouble and at one time were seen rolling around in the snow like puppies. A nest- box measuring 18 inches by 9 inches by 9 inches, was put in the flight in March and, of course, the birds were no longer shut in at night. They were interested in the nest-box at once and the hen started chewing up the old wood. I should perhaps mention at this point that the method I use for filling the nest box is as follows :--first the bottom of the nest-box is covered with perforated zinc sheet which is kept in place by strong wire netting, this allows a great deal of the liquid droppings to drain away, the bottom of the inside of the box is then covered with 2 inches of activated carbon which helps to keep the box " sweet " ; then I put in 2 inches of peat finished off with 4 inches of broken up rotten wood. This seems to do the trick. On 19th March two eggs were seen and the hen seemed to be sitting very tight. However, we then had a really frightful spell of bad cold weather and she came off. The eggs were then removed. Two more eggs were seen on 21st May ; though I can't be sure of the exact date of laying, it was certainly within a day or so of this date. The hen did not seem to be sitting all that tight and on 10th June I opened the box to see if the eggs were still there and was both delighted and surprised to find a very young chick which must have hatched that very day.

From then on frequent inspections were made and the parents did not mind at all and I had the pleasure of being able to show the chick to Dr. Searle who was over in England at the time. I put every type of food I could think of in the house, but the parents used only their usual nectar mixture and a little canary seed. The chick grew very well though much slower than parrakeets that I have bred. It started to feather up quite well, but left the nest on Tuesday, 9th August, with a great deal of nakedness. However, it was able to fly very well and is at the time of this report i.e., 27th September, fully feathered and of the same size as the parents. The only difference is that on leaving the nest its bill was a very dark brown which has now turned a dirty horn colour and the blue on the facial areas is less bright. The bird is now, of course, fully independent though is still in with the parents. At the time of writing the hen is again sitting on two more eggs so all looks well for some further youngsters. The nectar mixture I use is as follows :--one teaspoon of honey, one teaspoon of Horlicks and one teaspoon of Nestle's Full Cream Condensed milk to six ounces of water. I also have two beautiful Edwards's Lorikeets (Trichoglossus haematod capistratus) about to leave the nest, but more of them later. As described, W. H. Brown has bred Massena's Lorikeet Trichoglossus haematod massena. It is believed that this may be a first success. Any member or reader knowing of a previous breeding of this species in Great Britain or Northern Ireland is requested to communicate at once with the Hon. Secretary.
algorithms.table: * * * BIRD NOTES FROM CLERES--1966 By Jean Delagour (Cleres, France)
algorithms.bodyText: The weather during the breeding season of 1966 has been practically as bad as that of 1965 : almost continual cold and rain prevailed until early in August, which was also abnormally cool if not quite so wet ; only September was tolerably fine and dry. The result has been that many species of birds, which need a warm climate during their nesting season simply did not come into breeding condition and did not lay. Others dropped only a few eggs--often infertile ones. The group of birds particularly affected was that of the pigeons and doves, many of which did not breed, or only late in the season. No rare ones nested this year. Rheas were not very successful, one male only out of five hatching successfully a brood of twelve, two of them white. We now have six of the latter, but the four adults have proved to be all females. A three-year-old pair of Ostriches, born at the Paris Zoo, are in perfect condition and the female laid one egg.

Black and Black-necked Swans reared young, and also Orinoco geese (4), Andean (9), Ruddy-headed (2), Blue-winged (3), Cereopsis (2). Very few of the commoner geese were successful. Our old pairs of Stanley Cranes hatched two broods ; but during the last few years the young succumb to gape worms every time. We shall have to try to rear them in a brooder. Incidentally, several dozen of Stanley Cranes were offered for sale in Holland last spring. We got three additional pairs of Blue Crown Cranes from Tanganyika. A number of species of ducks have been reared, some by their parents, none of very great rarity. Our Eiders breed regularly. The aviary on running water for the smaller waterfowl proves to be very suitable. We have there African Pygmy geese, Cotton, Hottentot, Ringed, Laysan Teal and Bufheheads, as well as Spreos and Red- headed Marsh Birds. The Brush Turkeys insisted on building mounds close to public paths and when they were fenced off, refused to work elsewhere. Therefore no results followed. Siamese Firebacks, Edwards's, Swinhoe's, Cheer, Hume's, Elliot's, Grey Peacock Pheasants as well as Ceylon Junglefowl were reared ; also Bourke's and a few other Parrakeets. Some observations on the behaviour of certain birds may be worth reporting : A three-year-old Cereopsis male would never pair up with a female of the same age, so that they had to be separated after more than a year together. The same thing happened to Blue-winged geese. When such antipathy is shown persistently the only remedy is to try other pairings. A pair of Tasmanian Water Hens, in this park, although friendly, developed a craze for Screamers which they constantly followed, and they did not attempt to nest. They have been removed to the garden and now behave normally. A pair of Black Spurwinged geese, sent by the Pretoria Zoo where they were raised, first behaved normally ; but gradually the male became interested in the Australian Magpie geese, to the point of deserting his mate for them. The Spurwings were removed from the park and they have now resumed their former attachment. It is difficult to understand why birds of quite remote affinities should behave in such a way, as they not infrequently do, when they have practically unlimited space and mates of their own species available. I have had the occasion of watching recently African Black Ducks {Anas sparsa) on the lake. Their display is on the whole fairly different from that of the true Mallards ; but the males are inclined to join the latter and they perform completely the well-known " grunt-whistle ", which is typical of the Mallard-Pintail-Teal group. I am not certain that this display has been reported before.
algorithms.sectionHeader: DILLON RIPLEY-REMINISCENCES OF THE SEASON REMINISCENCES OF THE SEASON
algorithms.bodyText: By Dillon Ripley (Litchfield, Connecticut, U.S.A.) Although I have been watching the turning of the seasons with our waterfowl for thirty-five years now, the new calls, the new activities each spring as the crescendo of behaviour patterns rises to beat upon our senses like a vernal symphony never fail to bring a thrill. The weekends when we rush back from Washington to Connecticut carry us step by step forward into the heightening rhythms until the climax comes in May when much of our daylight hours are consumed by hunting for nests, or eagerly relating to each other ; " the Pinkfeet are on a nest again," or c4 it does look as if the Moluccan Radjahs might do something this time Alas the Moluccan Radjahs prove to be gay deceivers as they have all six years we have had them since bringing them back by air from New Guinea. The harsh rattles of the female, the head dipping minuet of the male lead once more to nothing. There is a brief renewal in the autumn. The theme recurs again as if in an autumnal recessional. It must be our climate. It is, perhaps, just too cold. Another pair of the same group of eight birds that we brought back has nested happily each year in the Caribbean Gardens in Florida to help to populate the avicultural world with a goodly number of progeny. So be it ; at least our Pinkfeet have nested twice now in the last two years, each time on the same island within a foot or two of the pre- ceding nest. The Chilean Bronze-wing Ducks, all fury and hellfire descend regularly on the Pinkfeet, but although the big geese were driven off the island bodily once or twice, they managed to hold their nest, and hatch out young. In spite of all the fuss and feathers raised by the Bronze-wings, their nests of large, brown poultry-sized eggs have failed to hatch. Somehow the Bronze-wings seem to have " protested too much When they got down to it, their eggs failed. Perhaps too much incitement is in itself not adaptive ? Some ecologist-behaviourists might agree. This 1966 season, from about 475 eggs gathered, we have reared about 150 birds. This rearing seems neither good nor bad, merely average. As always, we failed to find some nests, especially of teal and tree ducks which nest when the hay and weeds have become " jungley In the late autumn we may find the nests long since abandoned, the eggs conveying merely wistful speculations about possible owners. In this past summer, although the total season was dry, June was wet, and we lost a fair number of geese, six young Emperors alone, from aspergillosis. Among the geese, two subspecies of Canada laid, as well as Barnacle, Barhead, Pinkfeet, Whitefront, Emperor, Blue, both Snows, Ross, Hawaiian Nene, and finally one mysterious nest, the ownership of which seemed to fall between Black Brant and Redbreast. I made
algorithms.sectionHeader: DILLON RIPLEY-REMINISCENCES OF THE SEASON J 59
algorithms.bodyText: the mistake of removing the first egg (something I had never done before, but fighting and egg rolling had made me jumpy), and my effort to substitute large duck eggs failed, as our superintendent dourly assured me it would. No more small goose eggs were laid, and the single egg failed to hatch. Many full clutches of eggs taken from known parents, seem to hatch badly under artificial incubation. No one appears to have a sensible reason for this. Of a clutch of nine Green-wing Teal eggs we reared only one. Of two nests of Falcated Teal, of sixteen eggs, we reared five. Why should this be so ? On the other hand New Zealand Scaup laid eight eggs, we hatched six and reared four. Two fully-grown young in down simply dropped dead one day. One wishes year by year, that the answers were apparent to these peculiar ratios of egg- laying, hatching, and finally, successful rearing. Our own system is to start eggs in an incubator, let them go for five days or so until the embryo is beginning to become apparent, then place them under incubating hens. At the very end of the incubation cycle, we replace them in an incubator, in order to conserve the hens, and in this way keep them setting for more than one incubation cycle. This does not seem to be harmful to the hatching process, at least any more harmful than anything else. Would that we could learn something of the reason for the relatively low rate of hatching, below 33 per cent. The most interesting duck reared this past season from an egg just picked up at random in a nest of no known ascription, nor indeed a homogeneous nest, was a male Ringneck Duck, a charming North American species, often kept in captivity, but which has defied our efforts since 1940, to nest and rear young in captivity. Delacour lists only one breeding, at the Delta Waterfowl Station in Manitoba. It would be interesting to know if there are other records, sustained by actual proven birds reared ? Often we find diving duck eggs in other duck nests, sometimes as many as three species in a nest, although more usually two. The only Canvasback eggs we have ever had have been in such poly-parental nests. We find Redheads to be notorious in this regard (can they be called parasitic ? I think not in this sense), as also are Rosy-billed Pochard. Even Philippine ducks are becoming addicted to this habit, sometimes to the detriment of other, smaller species. For the first time this year we had a passage at arms between Common and Ruddy Shelduck over the same nest site, in a very large pen. The Common Shelduck won out, and all eggs taken from the burrow, proved to hatch out Common Shelduck. The Ruddy failed to lay at all. By now in October the days are shortening, the calls which have been subdued in August and September are resuming, and pair-formation is active among the ducks. Our Hawaiian Nene are already active, and territory-minded, and will soon go into the barn in which they have

160 K. M. SGAMELL-NEAR MISSES WITH VIOLET-EARED HUMMING BIRDS managed to breed each winter. And so in the autumn days, although the air is pungent with burning leaves, the rime heavy on the grass, and the morning mist thick and presaging winter, there is once again a hint of the turning cycle, the calls, the dimly-seen postures, that remind us of another season, another spring.
algorithms.equation: * \0x2756 * NEAR MISSES WITH VIOLET-EARED HUMMING BIRDS (\0x25A0Colibri coruscans )
algorithms.bodyText: By Mrs. K. M. Scamell (Newdigate, Surrey, England) I am never very willing to write about unsuccessful breeding results as I get too many failures to dwell upon them at length. One has to get conditioned to many failures and few successes with foreign birds in this climate of ours. However, on this occasion I have been asked by several people to set out our experience in breeding but not rearing this species in the hope that others may be more fortunate. We have rarely been without a Humming Bird at any time during the last sixteen years, but we have only attempted to solve the breeding problems during the last two years. It is one thing keeping a single Hummer, quite another to keep a pair or more in small garden aviaries. The males generally seek out their mates and destroy them by driving them from their nectar, thus weakening the females which would soon die if not separated. An alternative is to keep a number of Humming Birds in a large and heavily planted enclosure but from what we have heard and seen, the losses can be very great in these communal aviaries as the cocks are then in a position to attack each other as well as the hens ! There are exceptions to the rule and also non-breeding periods when it is safer to keep these birds together, but when they are in breeding fettle it is most difficult to know what to do. Most of our Humming Birds are kept in a conservatory which has a compartment for each bird with an outside flight to each two compartments which thus allows us to run the birds together or to let one out in the morning and the other in the afternoon. Colibri coruscans is a largish Humming Bird measuring about 5 inches. The general body colour is green with the chin, upper throat and centre breast violet-blue. The central tail feathers &re greenish blue and the remainder brilliant dark blue with a deep purplish blue sub- terminal band. A patch below the eye and continuing over the ear coverts is a glittering violet-blue. It ranges from Western British Guinea through Venezuela to Colombia and then southward through Ecuador, Peru, and Bolivia to N.W. Argentina. According to The

K. M. SGAMELL-NEAR MISSES WITH VIOLET-EARED HUMMING BIRDS 1 6 1 Birds of Colombia by R. Meyer de Schauer it is found in forest, scrub, and pasture land from sub-tropical to temperate zones. Our Violet-eared came from Ecuador. We purchased the male in late 1964, and the female in May, 1965. The sexes are supposed to be alike but Mr. Riley of Petcenta, Southall, where we made our purchases, was quite sure they could be sexed by the shape of the beak. From a number he selected one slightly on the small side and with a slight curve to its beak and pronounced it a hen and a hen it undoubtedly is ! The hen was placed in the same compartment as the cock in our conservatory and to our surprise he accepted her without too much sparring. They shared the same outdoor flight at the same time, but each had separate nectar tubes. Three months later we were presented with some Humming Birds by Dr. Beraut of Rio de Janeiro, and this necessitated some reorganization in the conservatory. As the Violet- eared were the toughest and the most " amicable " of the collection, they were removed to a birdroom in our small wood. This birdroom has a number of cages and five indoor flights which each lead to an outdoor flight. The two birds were given one of the compartments with the outdoor flight facing east. The compartment measured 3 by 2 by 6 feet high and the outdoor flight measured 8 by 2 by 7 feet high. Access between indoors and outdoors was controlled through a pop- hole door actuated by hand from outside the building. They were left free to shelter or stay in the flight until November when they were shut in at dark until the hinged door was opened in the morning. The birdroom was heated, but not thermostatically controlled ; only hardy birds were housed there, and in cold weather the temperature inside dropped to about 38* F. Unless there was a day frost they, like most of our birds, spent the daylight hours in the outdoor flight. On 19th March, 1966, we noticed that there were signs of nest- building. Dried grass strands were all over the indoor compartment (the birds were still being shut in at night). Eater in the morning the start of a nest was seen on a wooden batten 4 ft. 3 in. from the floor and which supports the wire-netting. The nest was about 2 inches from the nearest nectar tube, the base of which rested on the batten. It was difficult to change the nectar tube without touching the nest. Kapok, more grass, and moss were placed in the compartment. In the outdoor flight the two birds were seen flying vertically, bill to bill, until the hen settled on a low branch and the cock descended and mated. Nest-building continued daily and by 22nd March it was about 1 inch deep and was now touching the nectar tube ! It now consisted of moss, kapok, cotton-wool, all bound with fine strands of dried grass. At 9.30 a.m. on the 23rd there was an egg, very white and surprisingly large. It measured 15 by 9 mm. The male perched in the outside flight and kept up a monotonous " cheep-cheep " all day. We again saw the beak-to-beak flight, followed by mating on the same branch. The next

102 K. M. SCAMELL-NEAR MISSES WITH VIOLET-EARED HUMMING BIRDS day was cold with snow, bright sunshine, and a N.E. wind--almost a gale. The nest faced the open pop-hole which faced east. At nectar changing time, the egg was placed precariously on the edge of the nest, the hen must have dislodged it when leaving. A touch of my finger and it rolled back. In spite of the cold weather, nectar consumption was below normal. At 8.30 a.m. next day, 25th March, there was a second egg in the nest. We had already decided to remove the male if there was a second egg. This was done after a difficult chase in the outdoor flight with the hen shut in her inside compartment. He was placed in a nearby aviary. We bored a small peep-hole in the wall of the birdroom so that we could observe from time to time the compartment housing the hen and nest without ourselves being seen. She seemed very restless that day and little time was spent on the nest. As the days passed she now incubated for long periods, but did spend some time to feed. Her nectar consumption during this sort of weather was normally slightly less than a " Birdland " tube. It dropped first to about two-thirds and later to three-fifths of a tube. The separated cock in his nearby aviary was taking a full tube daily. In the other four compartments in the birdroom were breeding pairs of Bulbuls, Rothschild's Grackles, and Sunbirds. In addition, a number of Softbills were in the cages. It now became difficult to water, feed, and clean out these birds as the hen came off her nest most times when we entered, so one at a time all the birds except the breeding pairs were quietly removed to other quarters. When disturbed we noticed, from observations, that it took her a full minute to return to the nest after we left. She generally had a drink, then cleaned her beak on a perch, preened a few feathers and then hovered over the nest to alight gently. During incubation the nest was gradually added to. As the birdroom was too cool to breed fruit flies in volume for the expected chicks, we solved this problem by applying local heat from a horticultural heating tape around the large box containing overripe fruit and drosophila and their eggs. On 5th April, the fourteenth day after the first egg was laid, we thought it a good idea to refresh our memory on the possible incubation period. Turning to Birds of the World by Oliver L. Austin we read this could vary from fourteen to nineteen days. We also read that only in one group, i.e. the Violet-eared Humming Birds, was incubation and rearing shared by both parents ! And we had separated them ! A hasty search through our bird books brought two further confirmations. In the Avicultural Magazine for 1957, p. 86, Professor Berlioz was reported to have made a similar statement, quoting Dr. E. Schafer as having observed both parents sharing the incubation and rearing. A similar reference is also made concerning Colibri coruscans in Humming- birds by Crawford H. Greenwalt. It was too late now to do anything about it, but we were left wondering how well had the female incubated

K. M. SCAMELL NEAR MISSES WITH VIOLET-EARED HUMMING BIRDS 1 63 on her own and why should just one species of Humming Birds require the attention of both parents for these particular duties. When the nectar was being changed on 7 th April it was noticed how dark the eggs had turned. She was sitting very tight and at 5.30 p.m. on the 8th she came off the nest when I entered the birdroom and I saw one egg had hatched ! It was the seventeenth day after laying and the fifteenth day after incubation had commenced. The chick looked somewhat like a large spider ! The day was warm, 59 0 F, though dull with some rain. We decided to open the pop-hole door and give the hen free access to the outdoor flight for the first time since the second egg was laid. She was seen several times up to late evening hawking insects in this flight. The next morning was rainy, the second egg had hatched by 8.30 a.m. Somehow we didn't expect it as she was off the nest such a lot the previous evening. We watched her take fruit flies in the shelter and saw her feed both chicks. During the next two days we made many observations and it was very noticeable that the hen preferred the insects she hawked in the flight to the fruit flies in the shelter. The chicks were now showing brownish yellow down sprouting here and there and it was amusing to see such small objects sitting up to gape. I couldn't make out what certain little black rings dotted about the edge of the nest were until I saw one excrete ! Nectar consumption was now slightly in excess of the male's. It was much colder on the 12th and 13th, the outside temperature being about 39 0 F. Inside the shelter it was 6o* F. We were using an oil heater and fruit flies were in plentiful supply. I saw the chicks briefly, they were growing fast and the down was changing to brown/black. About 4 p.m. I spent some time at the peep-hole and saw her feed each of the young three times. Each time she perched on the nest, then had a drink of nectar, hawked in the shelter and followed this by brooding. 14th April was a most difficult day. It started snowing just before 8 a.m. and continued until 4 p.m. when about 6 inches of snow covered everything. With all our birds in aviaries and many nesting, we had a very busy time shutting in the shelters those birds which could be shut in and treble feeding those which couldn't. At 9 a.m. we shut the pop-hole door to the Hummers' outside shelter as the snow and wind were blowing directly on the nest and the shelter temperature was only 50 0 F. However, at dark the young birds seemed none the worse, and the nectar consumption was a full tube as against the male's seven- eighths of a tube. The thaw set in the following day though the temperature outside was only a few degrees above freezing. The afternoon was dripping and dismal and by evening it was raining. We kept the hen shut in all day. Both young birds were strong and observing them through the peep- hole at 1 p.m. the hen was seen to approach the nest and perch on the

164 K. M. SCAMELL-NEAR MISSES WITH VIOLET-EARED HUMMING BIRDS edge. Two heads and necks shot up like small snakes. She inserted her beak repeatedly, jerking food down. It was quite a vigorous act. The next three days were milder and very wet. The shelter tended to get too warm and we regretted that it was the only birdroom without thermostatic control. On 19th April nectar consumption was down to three-quarters of a tube. The chicks seem to sleep a lot. Their beaks are triangular in shape. The next day we began to feel that something was wrong. The hen brooded most of the time and the young birds did not gape as often as they had been doing. On the 21st the weather was fine and dry, the temperature outside was 50* F, so opened the pop-hole door again. Was still not satisfied that the chicks were progressing. During a thirty- minute period, the hen brooded about twenty minutes before feeding. The two small heads didn't pop up like they did and growth seems to have ceased. There is no feathering, only down and nectar consump- tion about four-fifths of a tube, the separated male taking a full tube in his colder aviary. The following day the two young birds were very weak, they scarcely moved except to breathe, and their heads rolled about. They no longer gaped and the hen couldn't feed them. She hawked occasion- ally but spent most of the time brooding. Both chicks were dead at 4 p.m. One was fifteen days old, the other a day younger. We removed the two dead birds and as the hen looked most dejected, we returned the male to the aviary and shut them in the shelter. They were both quite peaceable for a while and when we thought it safe to do so, ceased to observe them. However, on returning to the shelter about 6 p.m., we found the cock jammed head-first in the pop-hole door which was not tightly shut. We opened this door and released him into the flight but the hen went for him tooth and nail so we had to catch him up and put him back into his former aviary, a somewhat battered bird ! By the following day the male seemed to have recovered so he was once again returned to the hen. There were no fireworks this time, but for safety nectar was placed in the shelter and the flight. It would seem that the hen stayed in the flight the whole time and within a week she was not well, probably a chill, so we took to shutting them both in the shelter at night as well as giving terramycin in the nectar for five days. In a few days she was completely recovered. To revert back to the dead chicks, we still have them preserved in spirit. The cause of death in both cases could well be due to strands of cotton-wool getting into the gullet when the mother fed them. If the weather had been more suitable and she had had access to the flight the whole time she could have made a better job of cleaning her beak. The beaks are slightly open and what looks like cotton fibre is visible. We had a similar experience with a young Malachite Sunbird about three years ago when it had teased string stuffed down its throat from the hen's sticky beak. This we

K. M. SGAMELL-NEAR MISSES WITH VIOLET-EARED HUMMING BIRDS 165 managed to pull out and saved the bird but the Humming Birds were still very small and we did not suspect this was the problem. We were also rather obsessed with the need to breed masses of fruit flies and at first thought the lack of progress was due to lack of flies. This was not so. Throughout the incubation and rearing periods the hen was continually repairing or adding to the nest which in the last week had become very loose in structure. On 5th May, artificial nests were placed in various positions in the flight and shelter as it was by now obvious that she would never return to her original nest. They were made of Twilweld mounted on wooden bases. Overnight some moss and grass strands had been woven into one of the " nests 55 in the shelter and when this was added to during the next two days hopes ran high ! Nectar consumption rose, but nothing came of this attempt. Within a week the hen was again the stronger of the pair and though she stayed in the flight day and night, she would not allow the cock to leave the shelter. If he went outside when his nectar was changed, she chased him back again. He now started to moult and soon became a mass of quills and also grew new tail feathers. On 2nd June I noticed that a change had come over the behaviour of the two birds, in fact both birds were in the shelter together in the day- time. The cock was even tolerated in the outside flight and they were seen to carry out their beak-to-beak flight for the first time since early April. No nesting was attempted and the cock was still sprouting new feathers so his moult was incomplete. Hot weather had really set in at this time with temperatures in the low 8o's F. It was not until the end of June that the cock completed his moult. He still lurked in the shelter and when he ventured into the outside flight the hen displayed her brilliant ear coverts but not so the cock. This state of affairs continued throughout July but on 3rd August the hen started building a nest in the fork of a prunus tree about 6 feet from the ground, completely exposed to the elements and almost touching the wire netting dividing the Humming Birds from the Scarlet-chested Sunbirds in the adjacent aviary. The latter were nesting on the other side of the netting and the two nests were only a foot apart. The Humming Bird's nest grew rapidly and as before it was constructed mainly of cotton-wool bound with grasses and with bits of moss stuck here and there. On 6th August the hen was sitting and did not come off when I passed. At 10 a.m. she was drinking nectar so I had a quick look into the nest from the vantage- point of a step-ladder ! There were no eggs. Several times that day she was sitting and this u on " and " off" affair continued for some days. We gave her every variety of nesting material, lichen, moss, kapok, etc., but she preferred " Boots " new cotton-wool which she kept adding to the nest. She was sitting tight early on the morning of the 9th, but still no eggs ! However, about 5 p.m. she was off the nest and a quick look showed one egg at last ! The next two days were wet

66 K. M. SCAMELL-NEAR MISSES WITH VIOLET-EARED HUMMING BIRDS and warm and the hen rarely sat, but spent much of the time sparring with the cock. At 8 a.m. on 12th August she was sitting tight and did not leave the nest when I passed, nor did she at 9.30 a.m. when the nectar was changed. I felt sure she had laid her second egg. At 11 a.m. she was not sitting. Moreover the nest was destroyed and the pieces littered the flight. We shut the pair of birds in the shelter and after a search found two eggs in the grass, about 12 and 18 inches from the nest. They were unbroken so a crude repair job was done to the nest as quickly as possible and the two eggs carefully laid on top. We then caught up the pair of Scarlet-chested Sunbirds from the next flight (a few days before there were two chicks in their nest but this morning it was empty) and placed them in another aviary as it seemed possible that the two Sunbirds had pulled the nest to pieces through the netting, particularly as there were a couple of pieces of cotton-wool on their side of the netting. It was also possible that the male Humming Bird was the culprit but with three reports by noted ornithologists that both parents shared incubation, we were inclined to blame the Sunbirds. We next opened the pop-hole door and allowed the two Humming Birds freedom to enter the flight at will. The hen did so, but the cock stayed in the shelter and kept up his monotonous call. Neither bird showed any interest in the nest or eggs which were getting rain-soaked. After a few days we placed a sheet of polythene over the half of the flight in which the nest was located, but to no avail. On 1st October we removed the eggs. At the time of writing the cock is still in breeding condition (19th October), but the hen is not as strong as she was and we have separated them, the hen in the shelter and the cock in the flight. The weather is getting a bit chilly at nights so this arrangement now needs altering. I am thinking of putting the cock in the adjacent flight shelter for the winter and try and pair them up in early spring. We have tried several times lately, but I am sure the male would kill the female if we had not each time separated them after a few minutes. I feel sure also that the hen must be as strong as, or stronger than, the cock before it is safe to put them together and from our very limited experience this may also apply to our other pairs of Humming Birds. Dr. Beraut paid us another visit in September and when told of the destruction of the nest in August he said at once that it was the male. He added that all male Humming Birds in an aviary would destroy the nest in similar circumstances. In the wild state they can depart once the hen starts to incubate but in the confines of " an aviary-for-two " there is no second choice so the hen is not permitted to incubate. Dr. Beraut just did not accept that Violet-eared are exceptions to the rule. We are inclined to agree with him and, if there is a next time, out goes the male probably the day after the first egg is laid ! I think we blamed the Sunbirds unjustly though they may have joined in the

K. M. SCAMELL-NEAR MISSES WITH VIOLET-EARED HUMMING BIRDS 1 67 nest destruction once it started, particularly as, for some reason, they had just " lost " their own clutch which was the fourth this season with none reared ! It certainly hasn't been a successful breeding season taking it all round. The nectar recipe we have used during the last eighteen months for all our nectar drinkers was given to us by Dr. Beraut and we think it is the best of many recipes we have used in the last thirty years. It is also very easy to make and it keeps twenty-four hours in all weathers. We modified his recipe slightly by adding more water as we found it too thick for our cooler climate and I give below the one we use :-- Gevral-Protein J oz. ; White sugar 5 oz. ; Water to make 30 oz. The Gevral-Protein (made by the Lederle Laboratories Division of the American Cyanamid Co., Pearl River, New York, U.S.A.), is a white powder with a 60 per cent protein content plus minerals and vitamins. It is made into a smooth paste by the addition of a little cold water. The sugar is dissolved separately with sufficient nearly boiling water and cooled by the addition of about 20 fluid ounces of cold water. The cool syrup is then added to the Gevral paste, well stirred and made up to 30 fluid ounces by more cold water. Some of the proteins do not dissolve and fall to the bottom of the nectar tubes as a sediment. However, we have discarded the plastic closures supplied with the " Birdland " tubes and substituted corks so fitted that the thin end of the cork, when inserted in the tube, just reaches the spout. The sedi- ment, therefore, is constantly stirred by the Humming Bird's tongue so that the bird gets much of the Gevral. In addition, we usually shake the tubes once per day. Other nectar drinkers receive their supplies in the " Flow-matic " type of drinker. They all seem to get sufficient nutriment from this diet provided ample fruit flies are also available. At one time we bought our supplies of Gevral direct from the U.S.A., but I am glad to say that a London bird dealer now stocks it and we obtain our supplies from him. (Petcenta, Southall.)
algorithms.construct: 1 68 M. F. COUPE-BREEDING SCLATER'S CRESTED CURASSOWS
algorithms.sectionHeader: BREEDING SCLATER'S CRESTED CURASSOWS AT CHESTER ZOO
algorithms.bodyText: By M. F. Coupe (Zoological Gardens, Chester, England) Two pairs of Curassows purchased as Crested arrived at Chester Zoo on 13th October, 1961. On arrival they were thought to be Common Crested Curassow [Crax alector) or (Crax nigra) but subsequent investi- gation has revealed that they are the very similar Sclater's Crested Curassow (Crax fasciolata sclateri). One cock died during March, 1962, and a hen died during March, 1963. The remaining pair was housed in various aviaries throughout the Zoo, according to weather conditions or stock of birds at the particular time. The even temperament of this species enabled them to be mixed with a variety of smaller species. During 1965 eggs were laid, but eaten by other birds in the mixed collection ; however, neither cock nor hen Curassow showed any signs of incubation or protective instincts. With the coming of colder weather both Curassows were transferred to the then newly opened Temperate Bird House. With the start of the 1966 breeding season we looked forward to the Curassows laying again. They laid two eggs, but took no interest in them whatsoever, so they were removed to our incubator but unfortun- ately proved to be infertile. A second clutch of two eggs was laid during May on the rockwork surround near the waterfall in the Temperate Bird House. These eggs were incubated but were stolen, we suspect by children, just before they were due to hatch. The third clutch of two eggs was laid in a far safer position, on a three foot square platform at a height of fifteen feet in the Temperate Bird House (see photograph). This platform had been erected and filled with small twigs to encourage the Crowned Pigeons to nest. Incubation was undertaken entirely by the hen bird and she came off the nest to feed twice most days. The cock bird was not seen to incubate this clutch at all though he had taken part in the unsuccessful incubation of the previous clutch. He did however, take a keen interest in the nest and was never far away. The eggs were large, coloured white with a rough shell. On 7th August the two eggs hatched after an incubation period of twenty-nine days. Within hours of hatching the chicks became very lively and were running around on the nesting platform. This posed a problem for the keepers as the youngsters could not fly and were fifteen foot above a running stream and a public walkway. For some time continuous watch was kept, but it was decided that the hen and young would have to be moved. They were finally transferred to the long open air aviary in the Bird House. In the normal way all the birds at liberty in the Temperate
Avicult. Mag. 1966. Copyright j [Kenneth W. Green Curassow Nesting Site in Temperate Bird House To face p. 168
Avicult. Mag. 1966. Copyright ] [Kenneth W. Green Hen Crested Curassow and Chicks when 3 days old To face p. 169

M. F. COUPE-BREEDING SCLATER's CRESTED CURASSOWS 169 Bird House can fly into this aviary but we decided to leave the bob- hole open, thus allowing access to small species only. The following morning we decided to move the cock bird into this aviary as he was obviously so upset at being separated. A careful watch was kept on him for some time in case he should attack the chicks, but fortunately he proved to be the perfect father. The young Curassows are very well developed compared with similar species at the same age. As can be seen in the photograph, which was taken when they were three days old, the primaries are very noticeable. When four to five days old the chicks easily managed to fly into bushes in the aviary at a height of two to three feet, but spent most of their time on the ground, during day. At an age of twelve days they began to show aggressive behaviour, chasing a Spreo Starling from the food dish. From the start it was noticeable that the young followed either parent and kept close or underneath the tail, especially when very small. A good variety of food was offered including maggots, worms, hard- boiled egg, diced fruit, grain, greenfood and insectivorous mixture. Both parents fed the chicks, taking food in their beaks and calling the young to them. The chicks were very soon able to find food for them- selves, but even when they were eight weeks old the parents still called them when some very tasty food was found. To start with the young proved mainly insectivorous but ate more fruit etc., as they became older ; peanuts were also eaten readily at a later stage. At the time of writing, when the Curassows are a little over eight weeks old, they are approaching a Golden Pheasant in body size and have a tail roughly the same size in proportion to their bodies as the adults. They have both become increasingly darker coloured since hatching and are even beginning to develop the characteristic curly crest. With the arrival of frost this year it was decided to transfer all the Curassows to an inside aviary as these birds seem particularly suscept- ible to frost-bite. They are now accommodated in one of the aviaries inside the Temperate Bird House, but when the young are older the whole family will be released within the confines of the building. As described by M. F. Coupe, Sclater's Crested Curassow Crax fasciolata sclateri, has been bred at the Zoological Gardens, Chester. It is believed that this may be a first success. Any member or reader knowing of a previous breeding of this species in Great Britain or Northern Ireland is requested to communicate at once with the Hon. Secretary.
algorithms.sectionHeader: 170 SHEILA M. ROGERSON-THE CHINESE PAINTED QUAIL POSTSCRIPT ON THE CHINESE PAINTED QUAIL
algorithms.bodyText: By Sheila M. Rogerson (Whitegate, Cheshire, England) My article on Personal Observations of the Chinese Painted Quail which was published in the July-August issue of this magazine described the pleasures and trials of keeping and breeding these small birds. During their first breeding year, the pair in question produced four hens and three cocks which were eagerly snapped up by enchanted aviculturist friends. But this year our pair presented us with the traditional baker's dozen, thirteen in all and although many people came to see the fluffy bumble- bee chicks, only six went to new homes, possibly because out of the thirteen, there were only three hens. So seven little cocks stayed at home. It all began as the month of April came to a close. Our adult pair of Quail started in earnest on the family game and choosing a corner of the shelter, seven eggs were laid and duly hatched. Before we could accurately sex them another family was well on the way and the first chicks were moved to a separate flight. The second nest was made in the open flight sheltered by a large clump of grass and had been very difficult to find. Six little chicks emerged safely from this round and once again the adult hen decided to start another family. To avoid trouble with the elder chicks, the second clutch was put into another flight as by now the first chicks appeared quite adult. But space was quickly becoming scarce and it was a great relief to us when disaster struck the third nest. It began to rain steadily for several days and fearing the hen would suffer from the constant downpour, my husband placed a cover over the nest to protect it from the worst of the elements. The hen instantly took a dislike to this innovation and deserted her eggs. We decided to advertise the remaining seven young Quail and as they were all now in adult plumage, we put them together and awaited the customers. But by the time the advertisement appeared in the press all seven had indulged in a " free for all " and were a very sorry sight. Each dainty beak had savagely pecked the head and neck of its neighbour. One by one they were brought into the emergency ward (my kitchen) and were bathed and treated with antiseptic cream. Each was then deposited into separate aviaries and a frantic search was made for seven pots for seed and seven dishes for water. Grit was simply scattered on the ground. A visit to the local greengrocer produced seven wooden boxes which were hastily converted into miniature shelters. Thankfully, the chicks all healed rapidly and most of them have been found new homes. It will be a long time before I forget this incident and I can now better appreciate how " the old lady who lived in a shoe " felt when she also had so many children, she didn't know what to do !
algorithms.sectionHeader: JOSEPH BELL-NEW YORK ZOOLOGICAL PARK AVICULTURAL NEWS I 7 I NEW YORK ZOOLOGICAL PARK AVICULTURAL NEWS
algorithms.bodyText: By Joseph Bell (Assistant Curator of Birds) The most rewarding aspect of the bird breeding programme at the Bronx Zoo during 1966 was the opportunity of observing at close quarters the courtship, nesting, and rearing accomplished by a number of species in the simulated habitats that form the displays of the new Aquatic Birds Building. Inca Terns, Sun-bitterns, Kittlitz's Sandplovers, African Spur- winged Plovers, and Black-necked Stilts all produced young again this year but to this list we can now add Black-winged Stilt ( Himantopus himantopus himantopus) and Panama Boat-billed Heron ( Cochlearius cochlearius panamensis). The Boat-bills have tried to nest repeatedly during the last two years but this is the first time that they have successfully reared young. Also breeding for the first time in our
algorithms.table: collection were :-- West Indian Flamingo (. Phoenicopterus ruber). Chilean Lapwing ( Vanellus chilensis chilensis ). White-faced Tree Duck ( Dendrocygna viduata). Snowy Owls ( JVyctea scandiaca) nested for the first time this year but
algorithms.bodyText: failed to rear the two chicks they hatched. In all, forty-three species and subspecies, representing thirteen families, nested and produced young during the year and 143 birds were reared. Among the additions new to the collection and worthy of special note during the year were
algorithms.sectionHeader: 5 Horned Coot ( Fulica cornuta). 7 Black Oyster-catchers ( Haematopus bachmani). 6 Chilean Grebes ( Podiceps rolland chilensis ). 5 Northern Pacific Murre (Uria aalge inornata). 4 Rhinoceros Auklet ( Cerorhinca monocerata).
algorithms.bodyText: The murres and the auklets we acquired for the continuation of a long-term study of northern sea birds (Alcidae) are now on exhibit in a special Sea-Cliffs display here with a group of Tufted Puffins ( Lunda cirrhata) and Pigeon Guillemots ( Cepphus columba columba ) that have been in the collection for more than a year.
J. J. YEALLAND-LONDON ZOO NOTES

By J. J. Yealland The last occasion on which a new family of birds was received into the collection was in 1957 when the first of the Indicatoridae, the Cameroon Spotted Honeyguide, arrived from the Cambridge French West Africa Expedition. Now the first specimen of the Formicariidae, the Short-tailed Ant- thrush (Chamaeza campanisona ) has been presented by the executors of the late Capt. R. S. de Q. Quincey's estate. The recent history of this bird is that it was on a dealer's stand at the National Cage Birds Exhibition several years ago and advertised as a Brazilian Rail. It was soon noticed by Mr. Sawyer who bought it and it has lived since then in the aviaries of the late Capt. de Quincey. It is rather rail-like in its movements, for it walks and occasionally flirts the short tail and the wings ; in general appearance it is like a boldly marked thrush with rather long legs. There are some 200 species in this family, collectively known as Ant-birds and all live in South and Central America. There is consider- able diversity among them as may be judged from the popular names-- Ant-pittas, Ant-wrens, Ant-shrikes, Ant-vireos and so on. Most live in forests and some have the habit of following the armies of foraging ants in order to feed on the small creatures fleeing from them. The calls of some are said to be loud and penetrating. A new genus is represented by two Green-crowned Brilliant Humming Birds ( Heliodoxajaculajamesoni ) and new species by an Andean Humming Bird ( Amazilia franciae viridiceps) , two Black-headed Gonoleks (Laniarius barbarus erythrogaster ), a Splendid Starling ( Lamprotornis s. splendidus ) and a Philippine Flowerpecker (Dicaeum p. papuense). Two new subspecies are the Philippine races of Lonchura malacca (jagori ) and L. punctulata ( cabanisi ). Mr. J. O. D'eath has presented two White-necked Ravens ( Corvus albicollis), the first to be exhibited here for many years. Among birds bred in the Gardens are Erckel's Francolins, Sonnerat's and Tonkinese Junglefowl, Painted Quail, Night Herons, a Cattle Egret, Sarus Cranes, Grey-headed Gallinules and Crested Pigeons.

The Chairman welcomed Dr. Etienne Beraut, Rio de Janeiro. Philip Wayre showed his colour film " A Wind on the Heath ". This is a dramatic result of a 4-year study of the Breckland wilderness of East Anglia. There are many attractive shots of deer, foxes, Red- backed Shrikes and other animals and birds. As yet only the shadow of the developer has been cast over this unique area, but it can only be a matter of time before encroachment does irreparable damage. Philip Wayre is deserving of the thanks of all nature lovers for having recorded the scene before it is too late. The date of the next meeting is Monday, 21st November , ig 66 .

La Societe Ornithologique de France has published a special number of VOiseau et la Revue Frangaise FOrnithologie in his honour. * * * Eugenio Callegari, Ravenna, reports that the pair of Acorn Wood-
algorithms.bodyText: peckers which last year successfully reared families of one and two (1966, 78) has this year again reared two families, both of three young ones. Callegari says that he has only observed the male parent feeding the young.
