Collard, Managing Director, Natal Zoological Gardens, reports : " The following birds have recently been bred in our establishment :--Blue-naped Coly, White-backed Coly, Rameran Pigeon, Superb Starling, Crested Barbet, Forsten X Scaly-breasted Lorikeet, Black-capped X Purple-capped Lory. A pair of our Jardine's Babblers are presently nesting
algorithms.bodyText: The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds reports that for the fourth successive year two pairs of Ospreys nested. Very unfortunately both nests were destroyed by gales in late April. Three broken eggs were found beneath the tree of the main eyrie at Loch Garten, and one was destroyed at the other.

The U.S. National Zoological Park, Washington, has been particu- larly successful in breeding Kookaburras (Dacelo gigas ). A pair hatched in the Zoo in 1962, hatched and reared four young ones in the spring, and the female then laid again. There are at present ten adult birds in the collection, five of which were reared during 1965.

In the last number of the Magazine, page 140, I mentioned a pair of Yellow-billed Duck reported in Bokmakierie to be nearly fifty years old. In the September number there is a " correction ". R. A. Jubb now says : " The two ducks were alive at the outbreak of the 1939-45 World War and they are still alive. Their estimated age is twenty-eight years Hs sk When Charles Lucas, President, Avicultural Society of Australia, visited England in 1955 I had the pleasure of meeting him. Since then we have maintained the most friendly correspondence. Now the acquaintance has been renewed as Charles Lucas has recently again visited England. After attending a legal conference in Helsinki, accompanied by his wife he made short visits to Moscow, Berlin, Paris, etc., eventually arriving in London.

J. Rawlings, Kelling Park Aviaries, has successfully bred Ijima's Copper Pheasant, Syrmaticus soemmerringi ijimae. Some half-dozen birds were reared, but all, I believe, are very regrettably, being sent to America. This, the most beautiful of all Copper Pheasants is also the rarest in captivity. Its range is the southern part of Kiusiu Island, Japan, in the provinces of Osumi, Hyuga and Satsuma. Dr. H. E. Dresser named it in honour of Professor Ijima, Professor of Zoology in Tokyo University, who first sent him a specimen for examination, in 1902. Living examples reached Cleres in 1927. They did not, however, breed there but a male later produced hybrids with a Reeves's hen in Professor Ghigi's aviaries at Bologna, Italy.

In the Avicultural Bulletin , 1966, July, it was reported that David B. King, Ventura, California, had bred a " hybrid of an Aztec and a Jenday Conure David King informs me that the report was in error and that the hybrid was in fact Nanday X Jendaya. Two young ones were hatched in July, 1964. One died at about three months of age, but the other is described as a " beautiful bird, very much like a Nanday with a red breast This is possibly the first time this cross has been reared. But in the Avicultural Magazine, 1951, 70, Ken Stott, Jr., lists : " Jendaya Conure X Nanday Conure : Birds purported to be of this parentage produced an offspring in 1950 ", in the San Diego Zoo.

The remarkably successful, and much publicized, efforts of Peter Scott and the Wildfowl Trust to re-establish the endangered Ne-ne in the islands of Hawaii and Maui somewhat naturally rather over- shadow efforts in other fields. Sight must not, however, be lost of the endeavours of Philip Wayre to build up a stock of Swinhoe's Pheasant. The Ornamental Pheasant Trust has fifteen pairs ready to send to Taiwan (Formosa). Philip Wayre proposes taking these birds by air in April next year. It is to be hoped that he will be able to stay in Taiwan long enough to film the local fauna. Rather nearer home, on 4th August six pairs were released on Brownsea Island, Poole Harbour, Dorset, in an attempt to establish a feral population. Six pairs of Blue Eared Pheasants were also released at the same time in another part of the island.

W. D. Cummings writes that the following birds were bred at Keston during the past season : " Four African Grey Parrots, two Festive X Jamaican Amazon Parrots, three Leadbeater's Cockatoos, two Leadbeater's X Greater Sulphur-crested Cockatoos, six blue Ring- necked Parrakeets, six Barraband's Parrakeets, two Fairy Bluebirds, one Blue-shouldered Mountain Tanager, two albino House Sparrows (one a cock bird), one Rufous-bellied Niltava, and the usual number of Rosellas and Grass Parrakeets. The Chestnut-breasted Rock Thrushes had one fertile egg which they failed to hatch. The Leadbeater's X Greater Sulphur-crested cross is of particular interest because of the great difference in size of the two birds. The parents were two odd birds, paired together for convenience, and they seemed to take to one another straight away. The two young hybrids are dainty birds and take after their male parent in size, but are more like the Sulphur-crested Cockatoo in colouring. In immature plumage they are pure white with a yellow cheek mark. The base of the crest is yellow, shading to pale orange at the tip ".

It is customary for the Editor of Australian Aviculture to publish " The Prices of Birds " in the August number. This list gives what is considered the fair, average selling price between members. While intended primarily for Victorian members it is a guide for the whole of Australia. The prices refer to true, adult pairs, well acclimatized or aviary-bred, and in good condition. Finches, pheasants, quail, doves and pigeons, and parrot-like birds are all included, but the last named only are given here. The Australian common names have been retained but the prices have been converted, for the sake of convenience, from Australian dollars to United Kingdom pounds.

algorithms.bodyText: It is perhaps a little mean to tantalize parrakeet-starved European aviculturists with such prices. But just imagine, if only for a moment, buying pairs of say Crimson-winged, King and Splendid all for under #25! % sj: sfc In the March-April number of the Magazine I inquired which was the most numerous species of bird in the British Isles. There was, however, no response. Roger Bailey, B.T.O. News , July, 1966, gives the probable answer when he summarizes the Common Bird Census, 1965. He says that " enthusiasts mapped some 12,000 bird territories over widely spaced areas totalling 35 square miles of farmland and 3J square miles of woodland ". He has drawn up two lists giving the ten most numerous birds for farmland and woodland census plots respectively. Four species--Wood Pigeon, Rook, Starling and House Sparrow--have been excluded on account of lack of reliable estimates. The top three in each section are : Farmland , Blackbird, Chaffinch, Dunnock ; Woodland , Robin, Blackbird, Chaffinch. Members interested in such

matters should make a point of consulting Roger Bailey's informative summary " Top Ten It is now fashionable to call our old friend the Hedge Sparrow by its alternative name of Dunnock. Maybe this is just as well because the former is a misnomer --Prunella modularis is really an accentor not a sparrow. The name Dunnock is possibly derived from the Anglo- Saxon " dunn " meaning of a dark or obscure colour, and " ock " a diminutive. A. A. P.
algorithms.sectionHeader: REVIEWS COMMON CAGEBIRDS IN AMERICA. By V. Clear. Bobbs-
algorithms.affiliation: Merrill Company Inc., Indianapolis. 1966. Price 6 dollars.
algorithms.bodyText: This book is a brief and breezy general survey of aviculture, intended for the beginner and written specifically for the American market. It limits itself to typical cagebirds which are conveniently grouped under such categories as--singers, brightly coloured birds, hookbills and mynahs, and well-domesticated birds. The information is obviously based on considerable experience of bird keeping and the author's enthusiasm shows itself everywhere. It seems, to a disenchanted aviculturist's ear, to make everything sound so wonderfully easy, but perhaps this is a good thing in a book intended to fire the enthusiasm of the newcomer to aviculture. In addition to the earlier chapters which combine brief descriptions of a range of species with information on how to keep them, there are also chapters on care and management, illness, and on buying birds ; these again are based on wide experience and contain much useful information. The birds concerned are all foreign to the United States. I note that the author strongly criticizes the Australian Government's total ban on the export of native birds, but glosses over the similar ban, equally open to criticism, on the keeping of native birds in the United States. It is perhaps unfair to criticize the more academic points, but it is a pity that the erroneous belief in the hybrid origin of the Bengalese Finch should still be with us. It is a greater pity that the name " Button Quail " which specifically refers to birds of the genus Turnix of the order Gruiformes, should be used for a true quail of the order Galliformes which is almost universally known as the Painted Quail and which has nothing to do with the Button Quails ; and it seems unnecessary to use the name " hookbill ", which might refer to anything from a hawk to an albatross, for the Parrots. The book is copiously illustrated with colour photographs taken especially for the purpose. This is an excellent idea, but some- what marred in places by very poor colour values or impossible tints, and by the scruffy appearance of some of the birds. C. J. O. H.
algorithms.sectionHeader: NOTES I 79 THE IVORY-BILLED WOODPECKER, by James Tanner. THE ROSEATE SPOONBILL, by Robert P. Allen. THE
algorithms.bodyText: CALIFORNIA CONDOR, by Carl B. Koford. Constable and Co., Ltd., London, 1966. Price 16^. each. These three monographs, in the Dover Books on Nature series (New York), are unaltered, unabridged reprints of the Research Reports of the National Audubon Society. Those on the Ivory-billed Woodpecker and the Roseate Spoonbill were published in 1942 and the report on the California Condor in 1953. All are comprehensive careful studies and include accounts of the ecology and natural history of the birds with emphasis on their need for protection and suggestions for measures to be taken to this end. The books are fully illustrated with photographs and figures, with an attractive colour plate on the cover. In view of the present widespread interest in threatened species these informative monographs should find a ready sale. P. B-S.

algorithms.bodyText: Birds. Published for Shell-Mex and B.P., Ltd., by Discourses, Ltd., London, 1966. Price 12s. 6 d. each. These records of bird song recorded, edited and introduced by Lawrence Shove, are of a very high standard and the purity of the songs and calls is most pleasing, not the least asset being the lack of interfering background noise. It is stated that Mr. Shove is an amateur who is following the footsteps of the indefatigable Dr. Ludwig Koch from whom in 1964 he received a first prize in the B.B.C./Council for Nature wildlife tape recording competition. The prize was evidently well merited and all three records can be thoroughly recommended. P. B-S.
algorithms.figure: * * \0x2756 NOTES Some Comments on Derek Goodwin's Article " Keeping Doves and Pigeons :
algorithms.bodyText: Since so few members of our Society write about foreign doves and pigeons, it was a pleasant surprise to read Mr. Goodwin's informative and comprehensive suggestions in the July-August issue. This writer wishes merely to add a few more, which may prove helpful to keepers of these delightful birds. All seed-eating doves and pigeons are very fond of corn (maize), excluding only the smallest varieties for whom it is too large. They like especially pop-corn, which is a subspecies of Indian corn, its kernels being smaller and rounder than those of the parent form. Even in our mild Southern California climate. Bleeding Hearts, Key- West Quail Doves, Violet Doves, and many other species consume generous quantities of pop-corn summer and winter, even though they have a choice of other grains. All of them relish cracked sunflower seed and diced longhorn cheese, which they get

once a week. I should have mentioned above that pop-corn is somewhat more expen- sive than the regular corn, and I do not know under what name it is offered in England. Another pertinent point : fruit doves (they are kept by many fanciers in California, including this writer) being exceedingly voracious, quickly learn to descend to the floor of the aviary where food and water are available. Their menu is rather simple : boiled rice mixed with various fruits seems to suit them very well. In some instances they have been gradually weaned away from eating fruit and " learned " to feed on grains, which at first were mixed with the chopped fruit. Finally, one more comment. The simplest and most effective method of protecting aviary doves and pigeons from injuring their heads through flying against the wire- netting used as a roof for the flight, is to use a solid roof. This can be transparent or non-transparent. The writer's aviary--both shelter and flight--is covered with a solid, non-transparent roof placed sufficiently high to still admit ample morning sunshine. During the 9 years' use, not a single dove has injured its head or wings, since any and all disturbances and dangers from above by cats, owls, etc., have been completely eliminated by means of the solid roof.

algorithms.sectionHeader: INFORMATION REQUIRED REGARDING THE JAVA SPARROW'S BREEDING ABILITY
algorithms.bodyText: There are many old wives' tales in the world of aviculture, and the greatest wealth of these is to be found in the subject of breeding. I am hoping to get some quantitative information about the Java Sparrow's breeding abilities. Leaving the white and " calico " domestic varieties to one side, it seems that the grey wild form is very difficult to breed in confinement, and records are extremely infrequent--especially when one considers the vast numbers that are sold each year. There is something wrong with this because (a) the Japanese have domesticated it-- suggesting a degree of adaptability in the species to start with, and (b) when the grey bird has bred, it has behaved exactly like any other prolific and affable Lonchura -- taking to a wicker basket, budgie nest-box, etc., and rearing young on an all-seed diet in a mixed collection. A suggestion has been made (not by me, bnt I have some sympathy with it) that the main reason so few Java Sparrows breed in confinement is because the majority of the imported birds are males. Now I wonder if members who have bred, or simply kept, grey Javas could tell me :
algorithms.listItem: (a) If the birds did not breed, were the sexes positively known ? If so what were they ? (b) If the birds bred was it known positively if they were imported wild birds, or
algorithms.bodyText: themselves aviary-bred ? If sufficient replies were received, I would be happy to send you an analysis and any conclusions that may be drawn.

algorithms.bodyText: Reference was made to the Protection of Birds Bill in the January- February number of the Magazine (page 35) when it was reported that the Bill had passed its Second Reading in the House of Commons on 28th January, 1966. Owing to the dissolution of Parliament the Bill did not pass through its final stages and therefore became void. However, Lord Hurcomb reintroduced the Bill into the House of Lords during the present session, in July, and it passed its Second Reading. The Earl of Cranbrook kindly undertook to put forward an amendment providing that licences could be issued by the Home Secretary for " taking birds for the purposes of aviculture " and succeeded in securing the adoption of this amendment at the Committee stage of the Bill on 31st October. The thanks of aviculturists are due to the Earl of Cranbrook and also to the members of the sub-committee appointed by the Avicultural Society, Messrs. Colin Harrison, Claude Payne, and Philip Wayre, who have been ceaseless in their work in connection with the Bill. The Bill has also to be passed through the House of Commons but it is encouraging to know that the interests of aviculturists will be in the good hands of Mr. William Wilson, M.P. for Coventry South. A. A. Prestwich, Hon. Secretary.
algorithms.sectionHeader: REVOCATION OF PARROTS AND MISCELLANEOUS BIRDS (PROHIBITION OF IMPORTATION) ORDER, 1953
algorithms.bodyText: From 1 st November, parrots, budgerigars, and other psittacine birds may be freely imported into Great Britain, and importation licences will no longer be required from Agricultural Departments. Importations have hitherto been allowed only under licence because these birds could carry fowl pest virus. Long experience has shown that in practice they are not a significant factor in the introduction or spread of disease in this country.
algorithms.sectionHeader: 182 REVOCATION OF PARROTS AND MISCELLANEOUS BIRDS ORDER (1) The Parrots and Miscellaneous Birds (Control of Importation)
algorithms.bodyText: Order, 1953 prohibited the importation of psittacine birds, which include parrots, parrakeets, budgerigars, lovebirds, macaws, cockatoos, cockatiels, conures, lories and lorikeets. (Press Notice M.A.F.F. 3199 of 6th February, 1953 refers.)
algorithms.listItem: (2) The ban has been relaxed over the years to permit the importa- tion under certain conditions of pet birds, birds for medical or veter- inary research and birds for re-export. (3) Fowl pest is controlled in England and Wales by the wide use of inactivated vaccine. In Scotland a slaughter policy is still in force for the disease. (4) The new Order is the Parrots and Miscellaneous Birds (Prohibi-
